Crime_Name: Discrimination complaint under Canadian Human Rights Act
Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission's decision to dismiss the complaint was due to a time limit error or breach of procedural fairness
Evidence_Assessment: No ongoing discrimination found after October 2002; no valid reason to extend time limit
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision upheld; application for judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to justify late filing or procedural unfairness
Legal_Rule: Section 41(1)(e): one-year time limit for complaints; Section 44: dismissal if no inquiry warranted
Standard_of_Review: Patently unreasonable standard applied to Commission's decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived disability discrimination
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim not reached due to procedural dismissal
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of complaint (23.5 months after alleged act); absence of ongoing discrimination
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, procedural fairness
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: Section 41(1)(e), Section 44 of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Complaint of gender discrimination in employment
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in dismissing the complaint due to the one-year time limit
Governing_Law: Subsection 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: The alleged discriminatory act occurred in February 1999; complaint filed in December 2001
Burden_of_Proof: On the complainant to show timeliness or justification for extension
Credibility_Factor: Commission found no sufficient reason to extend time limit
Legal_Rule: Complaints must be filed within one year unless extended by the Commission
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged gender discrimination by employer (Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation)
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; dismissed on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of alleged discrimination (February 1999), date of complaint filing (December 2001)
Defendant_Response: Time-barred complaint; no justification for extension
Outcome: Commission’s decision upheld; costs awarded to respondent
Legal_Provision: Subsection 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Employment discrimination and failure to address harassment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in dismissing the complaint under paragraph 41(1)(e)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RCMP's failure to act after substantiating the complaint occurred within one year of filing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On complainant to show timely basis for complaint; Commission must justify dismissal
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Complaint based on documented harassment and institutional inaction
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Complaints must relate to acts or omissions within one year unless extended
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Sexual harassment by superior and employer's failure to take remedial action
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of RCMP’s inaction relative to complaint filing
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law and human rights law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: RCMP did not discipline the superior or implement corrective measures
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and procedural record of internal investigation and response
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Reconsideration of complaint by the Commission
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case remanded
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act

Crimes.Violation_Type: Workplace sexual harassment and institutional failure to respond
Crimes.Application_Facts: Alleged harassment by Chief Superintendent Soave and RCMP's failure to act post-investigation
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Constable Sharon Thompson, serving member of RCMP
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Dismissal of complaint based on time limitation grounds without full investigation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Canadian Human Rights Commission over internal RCMP conduct
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Timeline of harassment incidents and subsequent inaction by RCMP
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Commission failed to assess timeliness of employer’s inaction
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Complaint supported by internal investigation findings
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside; matter remitted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Reconsideration of the complaint by the Commission
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order for the Commission to reassess the complaint on its merits
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: RCMP’s failure to act occurred within one-year window, making complaint timely

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Complaint of sexual discrimination in employment
Legal_Provision_Involved: Section 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Outcome: Commission refused to deal with the complaint due to delay
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged rejection of junior driver position due to gender
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Institutional_Action: Commission exercised discretion to not proceed with complaint
State_Protection_Assessment: Commission assessed delay as prejudicial to investigation
Risk_Factor: Lack of documentation, witness memory impairment
Credibility: Claim not dismissed on credibility grounds but on procedural delay
State_Protection_Adequacy: Procedural safeguards followed; decision made in good faith
Risk_Nature: Procedural risk due to time delay

Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer erred in refusing the application due to the applicant's failure to attend the interview
Evidence_Assessment: Fax transmission records, consultancy firm's affidavit
Burden_of_Proof: Immigration officer must prove notice was sent; applicant failed to show non-receipt with valid reason
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claim of non-receipt deemed speculative; consultancy firm's use of correct fax number supported delivery
Legal_Rule: Immigration officers must prove they sent an interview notice to the correct address or fax number. Rejection is permissible if the applicant misses the interview without valid reasons
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged procedural unfairness due to non-receipt of interview notice
Outcome_on_Merits: No error found in the Immigration Officer's decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Transmission record of fax to correct number, affidavit from consultancy firm
Legal_Framework: Immigration regulations regarding notice and interview attendance
Defendant_Response: Notice was properly sent to the correct fax number used by the applicant’s representative
Outcome: Dismissed
Authority: Immigration Officer, Court handling judicial review

Legal_Issue: Whether statements made during patent prosecution can be used to establish estoppel against a patentee
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from initial refusal by Giles, A.S.P.; consideration of amended defense
Evidence_Assessment: File wrapper (patent prosecution) evidence was assessed but deemed inadmissible to alter patent scope or establish estoppel
Decision_Outcome: Paragraphs in the defendants' statement of defense alleging estoppel were struck out
Burden_of_Proof: On defendants to establish estoppel, which was not met due to inadmissibility of file wrapper evidence
Legal_Rule: The scope of a patent is determined solely by its issued claims; file wrapper evidence cannot be used to establish estoppel or alter claim scope in Canadian law
Standard_of_Review: Appellate review of a procedural ruling on admissibility of evidence and pleading sufficiency
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendants alleged equitable estoppel based on plaintiffs' statements during prosecution
Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of the plaintiff; estoppel argument rejected
Key_Evidence_Considered: Statements made by the plaintiff during patent prosecution (file wrapper)
Legal_Framework: Canadian Patent Act and common law principles of claim construction and estoppel
Defendant_Response: Asserted estoppel based on plaintiff's prosecution history
Remedy_Requested: Plaintiff requested striking out of paragraphs in the defense alleging estoppel
Outcome: Granted; appeal allowed, paragraphs struck out
Legal_Provision: Relevant provisions of the Canadian Patent Act and case law on claim construction

Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent infringed the applicant's trademark 'High Times' and passed off its business as associated with the applicant
Governing_Law: Sections 19, 20, and 7(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Affidavit evidence was used; respondent did not participate; evidence showed likelihood of confusion due to overlap in products and market
Decision_Outcome: Respondent infringed the trademark and passed off its business; insufficient evidence of depreciation of goodwill
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to prove infringement and passing off
Credibility_Factor: Respondent did not participate, which may have affected credibility assessment
Legal_Rule: Under sections 19, 20, and 7(b) of the Trade-marks Act, confusion between trademarks constitutes infringement and passing off
Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized use of 'High Times' in storefront, targeting similar customers, likelihood of confusion
Outcome_on_Merits: Applicant succeeded on infringement and passing off claims
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of 'High Times' in storefront, similarity of products and customer base, affidavit evidence
Defendant_Response: Did not participate in the proceedings
Outcome: Court awarded $25,000 in damages and $30,000 in costs to the applicant, plus injunctions against further infringement
Legal_Provision: Sections 19, 20, and 7(b) of the Trade-marks Act

Risk_Type: Risk due to state protection failure

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: Claim remitted for redetermination

Lack of state protection

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness or natural justice in refugee hearing
Evidence_Assessment: Credibility of applicant's claim regarding threats from GIA
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish basis for refugee status
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's credibility questioned by Refugee Division
Legal_Rule: Right to counsel is not absolute; adjournments granted reasonably
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged denial of procedural fairness due to lack of counsel
Outcome_on_Merits: No breach of procedural fairness found
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's claim of threats from GIA
Legal_Framework: Refugee status determination under Immigration Act
Defendant_Response: Refugee Division upheld decision; no procedural unfairness
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of refugee determination decision
Outcome: Application dismissed; decision affirmed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of correct legal test for best interests of the child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed due to procedural errors

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Statutory declarations, history of inconsistent statements, fraudulent documents

Legal_Issue: Appropriate penalty for contempt due to non-compliance with court order
Procedural_Stage: Sentencing after guilty plea to contempt
Evidence_Assessment: Defendant knowingly continued using trademark despite injunction and warnings
Decision_Outcome: Solicitor-client costs ($62,000), fine ($50,000 reducible to $10,000 if paid within 30 days), suspended 14-day imprisonment for director
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to prove contempt by clear and convincing evidence
Legal_Rule: Contempt penalties may include fines, imprisonment, or costs; deliberate defiance is aggravating, first offense and guilty plea are mitigating
Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of permanent injunction prohibiting trademark infringement
Outcome_on_Merits: Contempt established; significant penalties imposed with conditional reduction
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration of non-compliance (over one year), lack of apology, prior settlement offers, defendant’s awareness of injunction
Defendant_Response: Pleaded guilty to contempt, delayed compliance, no apology
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of injunction, correspondence, settlement offers, admission of violation
Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of court order, financial penalties, potential imprisonment
Outcome: Financial penalties ordered with conditional reduction for prompt payment; suspended sentence for non-compliance

Dispute_Type: Employment dispute involving termination and reinstatement
Legal_Issue: Whether the adjudicator had jurisdiction to hear the complaint under the Canada Labour Code
Governing_Law: Section 167(3) of the Canada Labour Code
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of an administrative decision
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence provided by the employer to classify the employee as a manager; new evidence disregarded due to procedural flaws
Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator's decision upheld; judicial review dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the employer to prove the employee was a manager
Credibility_Factor: Employer's failure to raise the managerial status issue before the adjudicator affected credibility
Legal_Rule: Division XIV of the Canada Labour Code does not apply to employees classified as 'managers'
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with jurisdictional questions subject to correctness
Grounds_for_Claim: Unjust dismissal under the Canada Labour Code
Outcome_on_Merits: Complaint allowed; employee reinstated with monetary relief
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of the employee's duties, authority over hiring/firing, and operational control
Legal_Framework: Canada Labour Code, Division XIV – Unjust Dismissal
Defendant_Response: Employer claimed employee was a manager to challenge jurisdiction
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence and submissions on employee classification
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn adjudicator's decision
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; adjudicator's jurisdiction affirmed

Prior_Criminality: Youth conviction became adult due to subsequent crimes

Prior_Criminality: Youth records accessible due to subsequent adult offenses

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a probation order
Dispute_Type: Deportation appeal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of IAD decision
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence about pregnant girlfriend
Burden_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities
Credibility_Factor: Use of 'convinced' did not alter standard of proof
Legal_Rule: IAD must consider humanitarian and compassionate factors
Grounds_for_Claim: Youth convictions should not count, situation of pregnant girlfriend ignored, incorrect standard of proof
Outcome_on_Merits: Application for judicial review dismissed
Defendant_Response: Appeal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Outcome: Deportation order upheld

Legal_Issue: Whether the Defendants infringed upon or passed off the Plaintiffs' trademarks
Procedural_Stage: Motion for injunctive relief by Plaintiffs; Summary judgment motion by Defendants
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of identical or similar trademarks, trade names, logos, or menus; no confusion or likelihood of confusion demonstrated
Decision_Outcome: No trademark infringement or passing off found
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs failed to meet burden of proving infringement or likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiffs' claims viewed as an attempt to stifle competition
Legal_Rule: Sections 19, 20, 22 (infringement) and section 7(b) (passing off) of the Trade-marks Act; summary judgment principles
Standard_of_Review: Summary judgment standard – no genuine issue for trial
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged mimicry of restaurant concept and unauthorized use of trademarks
Outcome_on_Merits: Defendants prevailed on merits due to lack of evidence supporting infringement or passing off
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of similarity in trademarks, trade names, logos, menus; no consumer confusion
Legal_Framework: Statutory framework under the Trade-marks Act and common law principles of passing off
Defendant_Response: Moved for summary judgment to dismiss the claims
Evidence_Type: Documentary and comparative evidence of branding and business elements
Outcome: Plaintiffs' motion dismissed; Defendants granted summary judgment with costs

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration requirements
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in denying the H&C claim
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Section 25
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant had unauthorized stay and prior rejections
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 25 allows discretion to grant permanent residency on H&C grounds
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim denied due to lack of exceptional hardship
Key_Evidence_Considered: History of visa extensions and unauthorized stay
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and personal circumstances
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permanent residency based on H&C grounds

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada after visa expiry, refugee claims rejected
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Korean national with rejected refugee claim
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant – overstayed visa and unauthorized presence
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – no finding of misrepresentation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction under Section 72 of IRPA
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: History of non-compliance considered but not determinative
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residency on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual or disproportionate hardship established

Crime_Name: Administrative Failure under the Income Tax Act
Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister of National Revenue breached the duty to assess the tax return with all due dispatch
Governing_Law: Section 152(1) of the Income Tax Act
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed delay was motivated by policy to deter participation in GLGI, not verification of claims
Decision_Outcome: Court declared the Respondent failed to assess the return with all due dispatch
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to demonstrate breach of statutory duty
Credibility_Factor: CRA's stated purpose vs. actual intent behind the delay
Legal_Rule: The Minister must assess returns 'with all due dispatch,' interpreted as within a reasonable time for proper administration
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper motive for delay; deviation from national policy; statutory non-compliance
Outcome_on_Merits: Application allowed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of local CRA policy in Winnipeg Tax Centre targeting GLGI participants
Legal_Framework: Income Tax Act, administrative law principles
Defendant_Response: Implied defense based on administrative discretion, but no justification provided for improper motive
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, policy directives, procedural records
Remedy_Requested: Declaration regarding failure to meet statutory assessment obligation
Outcome: Declaration granted; application allowed

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer erred in refusing the temporary resident visa application
Evidence_Assessment: The officer dismissed the application based on perceived weak family ties and insufficient financial resources, despite substantial evidence provided by the applicants
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate intent to leave Canada and meet admissibility requirements
Credibility_Factor: Applicants provided evidence of financial stability and familial ties
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA and its regulations, a visa can be issued if the officer is satisfied that the foreign national will leave Canada by the end of their authorized stay and meets other requirements
Grounds_for_Claim: Errors in decision-making process, including failure to consider relevant evidence
Outcome_on_Merits: The Federal Court found the decision unreasonable due to inadequate reasoning
Key_Evidence_Considered: Financial stability, familial ties in home country
Defendant_Response: Visa officer maintained refusal based on weak ties and finances
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of financial status and family connections
Outcome: Court allowed judicial review and remitted the matter for redetermination by a different visa officer

Legal_Issue: Did the Visa Officer err in refusing Mr. Sahota's application for permanent residence as a self-employed person?
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Sahota had over 30 years of farming experience but lacked knowledge of Canadian farming practices, specifics about his proposed farm, crops, geography, and business plan realism.
Decision_Outcome: The judicial review application was dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant (Mr. Sahota) to demonstrate eligibility as a self-employed person
Credibility_Factor: Limited understanding of Canadian farming and unrealistic business plan affected credibility
Legal_Rule: A 'self-employed person' must have relevant experience, intention, and ability to contribute economically to Canada.
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Visa Officer in assessing intentions and abilities of applicant
Outcome_on_Merits: Visa Officer’s decision upheld as reasonable
Key_Evidence_Considered: Farming experience, knowledge of Canadian agriculture, proposed business plan, understanding of geography and crops
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Defendant_Response: Visa Officer found insufficient intention and ability based on lack of detailed planning and local knowledge
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, application materials, officer's assessment
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn refusal of permanent residency application
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; refusal of residency upheld
Legal_Provision: Section related to self-employed persons under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations

Risk_Assessment: High risk if returned to Pakistan

Legal_Issue: Whether FMV method can be used for valuing asphalt under Excise Tax Act when materials are customer-supplied
Evidence_Assessment: Review of applicable laws, memoranda, and party submissions
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to justify use of FMV and claim for refund
Credibility_Factor: Plaintiff's change in valuation method; reliance on Revenue Canada's representations
Legal_Rule: FMV cannot be used if customer supplies materials; all material costs must be included in tax calculation
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation of Excise Tax Act and administrative guidance
Grounds_for_Claim: Plaintiff sought refund based on retroactive switch to FMV method
Outcome_on_Merits: No refund granted; plaintiff not permitted to use FMV with customer-supplied materials
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of determined value method initially, subsequent switch to FMV, nature of material supply
Legal_Framework: Excise Tax Act and related administrative memoranda
Defendant_Response: Opposed retroactive method change and use of FMV with customer-supplied materials
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, statutory provisions, administrative guidance
Remedy_Requested: Refund of excise tax based on FMV method
Outcome: Appeal dismissed, no costs awarded

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's credibility findings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found inconsistencies such as 2001 passport with valid visa despite claim of non-use

Legal_Issue: Reasonable grounds for denial

Violation_Type: Failure to establish persecution or lack of state protection

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 68(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ferri, a permanent resident, was convicted of a narcotics offense, triggering automatic cancellation of his deportation stay under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Constitutional challenge to s. 68(4) raised during appeal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD has jurisdiction to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction record, IRPA provisions, Charter arguments
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacks jurisdiction to consider constitutionality of s. 68(4)
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation and hearing of constitutional challenge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of IRPA sections 162(1) and 68(4)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Explicit statutory language of s. 68(4) limits IAD’s role to factual determinations, overriding general jurisdiction under s. 162(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Deportation order under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutionality of deportation provisions in immigration law
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld due to lack of IAD jurisdiction over constitutional issues
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of Charter rights due to denial of appeal rights after second serious offense
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Cancellation of deportation stay and termination of appeal
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Permanent resident seeking protection from deportation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of heroin for the purpose of trafficking

Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal before IAD and subsequent judicial review

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed constitutional challenge; Federal Court upheld decision

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 68(4) IRPA removes IAD's ability to stay deportation upon second serious offense
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Charter challenge to s. 68(4) IRPA based on fairness and right to appeal
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Constitutional challenge not heard; deportation process resumed
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Ferri argued that s. 68(4) violates Charter rights
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal conviction documentation
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation and constitutional review by IAD
Crimes.Outcome: Remedy denied due to statutory bar on IAD jurisdiction

Legal_Provision_Violated: Failure to submit Personal Information Forms (PIF) within 28 days
Application_Facts: Applicants missed PIF deadline due to language barriers, financial constraints, and delays in securing legal counsel
Procedural_Issue: RPD declared claim abandoned without assessing readiness to proceed or applying correct legal test
Evidence_Used: Applicants' explanations for delay: language, financial issues, legal representation delays
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD did not consider sufficient context for late submission
Outcome: Judicial review granted; RPD decision quashed
Remedy_Sought: New hearing before a different RPD member
Legal_Standard_Applied: Whether there was a reasonable explanation or readiness to proceed
Decision_Rationale: RPD erred by applying 'exceptional circumstances' standard instead of readiness to proceed; incorrect legal test used

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to reject Mr. Bohorquez's refugee claim reasonable based on credibility findings?
Outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed, and the case is remitted for re-determination by a different panel.
Credibility_Assessment: The Board overlooked key evidence (threat to mother, land registry system misunderstanding, FARC's tracking ability), leading to unreasonable credibility findings.
Basis_of_Claim: Mr. Bohorquez claimed refugee status due to threats from FARC after refusing to inflate property values.
Application_Error: Overlooked key evidence in credibility assessment
Legal_Standard: The Board must reasonably assess evidence and consider all relevant facts when making credibility determinations.
Application_Factor: Unreasonable credibility findings due to ignored evidence
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision overturned; case remitted for re-evaluation by new panel

Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's decision to deny Wang a student permit was reasonable and complied with natural justice requirements
Outcome: The Federal Court dismissed Wang's application for judicial review
Credibility_Assessment: Wang lacked proof of her parents' financial stability, which affected assessment of her intent to return to China
Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence regarding financial support and ties to China
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient evidence of ties to China and financial support for study in Canada
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Financial stability of parents and likelihood of returning to home country
Assessment_Standard: Patent unreasonableness standard for fact-based decisions by visa officers
Legal_Standard: Natural justice requires adequate reasons, balanced with administrative efficiency
Application_Factor: Student visa eligibility based on financial support and non-immigrant intent

Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support investigator's finding of no harassment
Evidence_Credibility: Credible, based on court's reasonableness review

Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess cumulative evidence of persecution
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant is a Tamil who fled Sri Lanka due to persecution by government forces and LTTE; claims mistreatment by police and harassment by LTTE; fears future persecution based on ethnicity and political opinion
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal failed to adequately consider all relevant factors in refugee determination; error in assessment of cumulative persecution evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal dismissed key evidence without proper reasoning
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on inadequate analysis of credible incidents
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; tribunal decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Granting of refugee protection in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of refugee claim by a different tribunal panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under s. 2(1) of the Immigration Act
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal erred by narrowly focusing on applicant's age and isolated incidents, failing to assess cumulative risk of persecution based on race, nationality, and political opinion
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether procedural fairness was breached by not considering applicant's response letter
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant claimed to have sent a response; burden on applicant to prove receipt

Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Burden on applicant to ensure delivery and receipt of response
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to confirm receipt of response letter

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Alleged response letter not received or considered
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of modern communication methods allowing tracking
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found

Violation_Type: Failure to meet burden of proof for refugee status
Lack of nexus to Convention grounds
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96 and 97
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution by uncle and NDC officials in Ghana after leaving political party; reported attack to police but could not identify assailants; cited political opinion as basis for fear
Claimant_Status: Applicant for refugee protection in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claimant was outside country of nationality seeking protection
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on Ghana's police reforms
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence that state was unable or unwilling to protect
No identification of attackers limited police response
Lack of evidence linking harm to Convention grounds
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant did not sufficiently demonstrate state protection failure or persecution nexus
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to rebut presumption of state protection; insufficient evidence of state inability or unwillingness to act; no established nexus between alleged harm and Convention grounds

Dispute_Type: Credibility of applicant's religious identity and church membership
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's credibility finding
Outcome: Board's decision set aside, case remitted for redetermination
Credibility_Assessment: Found lack of credibility due to inconsistencies in church membership numbers and insufficient Christian knowledge
Evidence_Type: Applicant's testimony, claimed church membership, religious knowledge
Legal_Provision: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) – Refugee definition
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Perceived inconsistencies in church membership numbers and level of Christian knowledge
Application_Error: Overly microscopic scrutiny of minor inconsistencies
Assessment_Standard: Plausibility and reasonableness of credibility findings
Evidence_Ignored: Contextual explanation for minor discrepancies in religious knowledge and membership details
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard with high deference to administrative decision-makers
Application_Factor: Applicant's ability to demonstrate genuine religious belief and membership
Decision_Outcome: Original dismissal overturned; claim remitted for new hearing
